awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Oscillator Processing Unit - Physical Reservoir Computing on the Edge
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will result from creating the Oscillator Processing Unit (OPU), a computational processor that would be a disruptive technology for analog computing devices operating at the network edge. The edge computing device market is projected to reach $157B by 2032. Expanding on this, machine learning, especially deep neural networks (DNNs), relies on cloud infrastructure to conduct massive computation for both model training and inference, so OPUs would have beneficial security and environmental impacts since they would reduce reliance on the cloud. The proposed OPUs could overcome the von Neumann bottleneck while also enabling a smaller form factor, increased energy efficiency, and faster speeds. As the US seeks to reduce reliance on foreign microchip manufacturers, OPUs could also provide a powerful, viable alternative that could be manufactured in the US. The technological impacts of this project would result from a more fundamental understanding of how oscillators, which are one of the most prolific dynamic systems in the universe, can also be reconsidered as physical computers. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to leverage two types of oscillator-based neuromorphic computers. By exploring the dynamics of oscillator computers, an improved understanding of how nonlinear dynamics are translated into computational ability will be developed. Further, this is expected to provide insights into how optimal oscillator cores could be constructed for Oscillator Processing Units (OPUs). These enhanced OPUs will converge two separate methods of analog computing: physical reservoir computers and adaptive oscillators. Ultimately, since an oscillator core’s memory and processing are not independent, OPUs could provide a solution to the von Neumann bottleneck. This work would establish a fundamental scientific understanding of the link between physics and information. Leveraging these two disparate forms of neuromorphic intelligence will also be the basis of a powerful Oscillator Processing Unit capable of acting as both an AI inference processor and a generalized computing processor.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Oscillator Processing Unit (OPU) is an oscillator-based processor, which functions as both memory and processor. It is a non-von Neumann architecture, so it avoids the von Neumann bottleneck of data transfer. In this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project, a new type of OPU was created that utilizes a synergy between two different types of analog computing: physical reservoir computers and adaptive oscillators. The technological innovation is an enhanced analog processor that can simultaneously act as an analog neural network, an analog signal analyzer, a morphable logic gate, an energy harvester, a cybersecurity authentication key, and a noise-utilizing signal booster. The OPU provides benefits to speed through a type of in-memory processing and computational power through nonlinear dynamics. The OPU is an analog processor that can compute AI inference with almost no latency while also being energy efficient, easy to manufacture, not reliant on pre- or post-processing, and capable of general purpose computing tasks.

 

The intellectual merit of this project is that it has provided significant insights into how nonlinear dynamics are translated into a form of memory and processing. The OPU is analogous to an analog neural network, and it was found that a single oscillator can function as hundreds of long-short term memory (LSTM) units. This implies a powerful scaling relationship, which should greatly reduce the fabrication difficulty of the OPU. The OPU innately functions as an analog signal analyzer, as the adaptive oscillator core directly learns and stores frequency and amplitude information. A streamlined approach to use the OPU as a morphable logic gate was also presented. Since a single oscillator can function as all the basic logic gates simultaneously, this means that it can be used as the building block of a morphable CPU. The Duffing adaptive oscillator core of the OPU can be directly used as a vibratory energy harvester. The Duffing adaptive oscillator was verified to function as a physical unclonable function, which means that it can be used as an authentication key. The Duffing adaptive oscillator was shown to boost signals in the presence of noise and to even use noise energy to increase its own learning rate. Since all of these functionalities are innate to the OPU, it reduces the need of other types of computer hardware. Several different prototypes were constructed from different physical oscillators, using both electrical and mechanical systems. This project has contributed to a better understanding of the connection between nonlinear physics and computing.

 

The broader impact of this project is that it has laid the groundwork for the OPU, which should provide neuromorphic computing at real-time speeds.  The OPU will have a significant economic impact, since there is a need for faster and more powerful processors. The OPU will be an enabling tool for many applications within the edge processor market, such as real-time data processing and predictive maintenance. As the US seeks to reduce reliance on foreign microchip manufacturers, OPUs could also provide a powerful, viable alternative that could be manufactured in the US. Since deep neural networks (DNNs) rely on the cloud infrastructure to conduct massive computation for both model training and inference, OPUs would have beneficial security and environmental impacts since they would reduce reliance on the cloud. The scientific impacts of this project would be a more fundamental understanding of how oscillators, which are one of the most prolific dynamic systems in the universe, can also be reconsidered as physical computers. Educational impacts of this project focused on scientific communication activities and an undergraduate research internship.
